headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the WEC Energy Group's conference call for third quarter 2017 results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions]Before the conference call begins, I remind you that all statements in the presenta
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the WEC Energy Group's conference call for third quarter 2017 results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions]
Before the conference call begins, I remind you that all statements in the presentation, other than historical facts, are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that are subject to change at any time. Such statements are based on management's expectations at the time that they are made. In addition to the assumptions and other factors referred to in connection with statements, factors described in WEC Energy Group's latest Form 10-K and subsequent reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated. During the discussion, referenced earnings per share will be based on diluted earnings per share unless otherwise noted.
After the presentation, the conference will be open to analysts for questions and answers. In conjunction with this call, a package of detailed financial information is posted at wecenergygroup.com. A replay will be available approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of this call.
And now it is my pleasure to introduce Mr. Gale Klappa, Chairman and Interim Chief Executive Officer of WEC Energy Group. Mr. Klappa, the floor is yours.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us as we review our performance for the third quarter of this year. Now before we dive into our update this afternoon, I'd like to take just a moment to thank you for the incredible outpouring
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us as we review our performance for the third quarter of this year. Now before we dive into our update this afternoon, I'd like to take just a moment to thank you for the incredible outpouring of prayers and support and good wishes for Allen Leverett following his stroke earlier this month. I can tell you that Allen has been released from the hospital and is making progress in his recovery. I will continue to serve as Interim Chief Executive for as long as necessary, but the ultimate goal is obviously to bring Allen back. But again, your kindness and concern meant a great deal to Allen and his family, and a great deal to all of us as well. My thanks. 
Now I'd like to introduce the members of our senior team who are here with me today. We have Scott Lauber, our Chief Financial Officer; Jim Schubilske, Treasurer; Susan Martin, General Counsel; Bill Guc, our Controller; and Beth Straka, Senior Vice President of Corporate Communications and Investor Relations.
We'll begin with our third quarter results. As I'm sure you saw from our news release this morning, we reported third quarter earnings of $0.68 a share. We delivered a solid third quarter, largely driven by effective cost controls.
Our focus on cost management and efficiency gains was a major factor in offsetting the impact of mild summer weather compared to last year's third quarter. Those cool temperatures were particularly noticeable during August, which is normally 1 of the 2 warmest months in the Midwest.
Next I'd like to brief you on several development on the regulatory front and on our capital investments. On August 10, the Wisconsin Public Service Commission unanimously approved our proposed rate settlement. We received our final written order on September 8. Under the approved settlement, base rates for all of our Wisconsin utilities will remain flat for 2018 and for 2019. In total, this will keep base rates flat for 4 years, and essentially gives our customers price certainty through 2019.
The earnings sharing mechanisms that have been in place will be extended through 2019 at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas and a similar mechanism will now be in place for 2018 and 2019 at Wisconsin Public Service. Now just a reminder, customers and stockholders share equally in the first 50 basis points of earnings above our allowed rate of return. Anything above the first 50 basis points will flow completely to customers. 
Now as part of the agreement, we've also expanded and made permanent certain pricing options for our large electric customers. These options will continue to help many of our customers grow their businesses, create jobs and reduce their energy costs. 
Turning to Michigan. I'm pleased to report that we obtained final regulatory approval just yesterday for the construction of new natural gas-fired generation in the Upper Peninsula. We also received all local approvals that are needed to move forward with the project. Our plan is to bring those facilities into commercial service in 2019. And at that time or soon thereafter, we expect to retire our coal-fired power plant at Presque Isle. The approved project calls for a $265 million investment in reciprocating internal combustion engines. It will be capable of generating up to 180 megawatts of electricity. These units, which will be owned by our utility subsidiary in Michigan, Upper Michigan Energy Resources, provide a long-term generation solution for customers in the Upper Peninsula, and that includes the iron ore mine owned by Cleveland Cliffs.
And now for an update on Illinois. We continue to make progress on the Peoples Gas system modernization program. Since we acquired Peoples Gas, we've made significant improvements in a number of important metrics. We've lowered contractor construction costs by 15%; we've achieved a 70% decline in customer complaints; construction timelines have been reduced by more than 25%; and I'm pleased to say that our working relationship with the city of Chicago is greatly improved.
Our system modernization program, as you've heard, is designed to make the gas distribution network in Chicago safer, more reliable, less expensive to maintain. You may recall, we still have an open bucket underprepared approach on this long-term project. We expect a decision by the Illinois Commerce Commission by year and. And consistent with our 2017 plan, we are on track to invest approximately $300 million on the effort in Chicago this year. 
Turning now to our operations in Minnesota. On October 13, Minnesota Energy Resources filed a rate case with the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission. We're seeking to increase natural gas base rates by $12.6 million or approximately 5%. And we've also requested, under procedures available in Minnesota, to self-implement an increase of $9.5 million or 3.8% effective January 1 of 2018.
A final decision on new permanent rates is not expected until the first quarter of 2019. I'd also like to update you on our recent FERC decision related to system support resource payments for the Presque Isle power plant in Michigan. In its decision, FERC ordered a refund of $22.6 million associated with the payments that we received for the period February 2014 through January of 2015.
As you may recall, this is very close to the amount the administrative law judge recommended last year. So consistent with our previous statements, the amount of the refund will not result in a dollar for dollar reduction in net income and we have taken the FERC decision into account for our year-end guidance.
Next I'd like to remind everyone that we will be rolling out our new 5-year capital forecasts at the EEI Finance Conference in early November. Over the past few months, Allen shared the developing plan with me in my role as Chairman of the Board. In the past few weeks, I have of course reviewed the capital plan in detail, and I share Allen's optimism about the direction of the plan. Now one piece of that new 5-year plan has just been put in place.
Our Wisconsin Public Service utility in Green Bay, along with Wisconsin Power and Life and Madison Gas and Electric, have purchased the forward wind energy center from Invenergy. The total purchase price is approximately $174 million. We will own 44.6% of the facility with an investment of approximately $78 million. It consists of 86 GE wind turbines with a capacity of about 130 megawatts. The wind farm is located 10 miles south of [indiscernible] in the eastern part of the state. If approved, Wisconsin Public Service customers will see real savings because we will be able to eliminate the existing power purchase agreement.
Pending regulatory approvals closing on the forward wind center could take place next spring. Again, we look forward to sharing more about our new 5-year capital plan at EEI and we really look forward to the opportunities that lie ahead.
In speaking of opportunity, you may have heard about the blockbuster announcement this summer. The announcement at Foxconn has chosen Wisconsin for one of the largest economic development projects in American history. Based on revenue, Foxconn is the fourth largest tech company in the world. And Foxconn has decided to bring a brand-new technology called 8 K to the United States. The company plans to invest $10 billion to build a massive production plant that could employ as many as 13,000 people in Wisconsin County just south of Milwaukee. We expect the electric demand for this Foxconn campus to be more than 200 megawatts. That's approximately 3x the size of our current largest Wisconsin customer. And that does not include the demand that will develop from the suppliers that will also need to locate near the Foxconn facility. Foxconn has chosen a site in Southeastern Wisconsin that is perfectly situated on our transmission network. We will not need to build any new generation. Our state-of-the-art network is well equipped today to provide reliable low-cost energy to Foxconn. 
And on top of that, folks, if you like gummy bears and you know who doesn't, I have more news for you. German candymaker Haribo has also selected Wisconsin for its first-ever manufacturing facility in North America. So as you can see, the manufacturing economy in Wisconsin is alive and well. 
And now with details on our third quarter results and our outlook for the remainder of 2017, here's our Chief Financial Officer, Scott Lauber. Scott?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gale. Our GAAP earnings were unchanged from the third quarter of 2016 at $0.68 per share. You may recall that our 2016 third quarter earnings included $0.01 of acquisition costs. Excluding these costs, our adjusted earnings were $0.69 in the th
componenttext:
Thank you, Gale. Our GAAP earnings were unchanged from the third quarter of 2016 at $0.68 per share. You may recall that our 2016 third quarter earnings included $0.01 of acquisition costs. Excluding these costs, our adjusted earnings were $0.69 in the third quarter 2016. Our results were primarily driven by returns to normal weather condition, offset by positive impact on cost control. Weather in 2016 was 43% warmer than normal in Southeastern Wisconsin. The earnings packet placed on our website this morning includes a comparison of third quarter and year-to-date 2017 and 2016 results for GAAP and adjusted. There are no adjustments made to GAAP earnings in 2017. 
My focus will be on the quarter, beginning with operating income by segment and then other income, interest expense and income taxes. Referring to Page 9 of the earning packet, our consolidated operating income in the third quarter of 2017 was $393.6 million compared to an adjusted $402.5 million in the third quarter of 2016, a decrease of $8.9 million.
Starting with Wisconsin segment, operating income decreased $19.4 million quarter-over-quarter. Lower margin was driven by a return to normal weather and a normal fuel recovery pattern. This was offset by operations and maintenance expense that was $39.9 million lower compared to the third quarter of 2016. Last year, we recorded $18.6 million in operations and maintenance expense related to the earnings sharing mechanism in place at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas.
In the third quarter of 2017, our Illinois segment recognized operating income increase of $800,000 compared to the third quarter of 2016. The increase is primarily driven by continued investment in the gas system modernization program.
As expected, operating loss in our Other States segment increased $2.1 million, driven by higher depreciation and amortization expense resulting from an increase in capital investments in our gas distribution utilities.
Turning now to our 9 utility energy infrastructure segment. As a reminder, this segment contains the operations of Bluewater Natural Gas Holding, which is acquired on June 30 of this year as well as the results of the Power the Future plants. For the third quarter, operating income in the segment was up $9.7 million. Bluewater's Natural Gas Holding contributed $5.9 million to operating income in 2017. Operating income from our Power the Future plants increased $3.8 million, reflecting the additional investment at these plants since the third quarter of 2016.
Operating income at our corporate and other segment was $1.1 million for the third quarter of 2017, an increase of $2.1 million from the adjusted operating loss in the third quarter of 2016. Taking the changes for these segments together, we arrived at $8.9 million decrease in adjusted operating income. 
During the third quarter of 2017, earnings from our equity investment in American Transmission Company totaled $39.2 million, an increase of $900,000 compared to the same quarter of 2016.
Other income net increased by $8.9 million quarter-over-quarter. This was largely due to 2 items, higher investment gains related to our deferred compensation plan and we incurred losses in our third quarter of 2016 related to the disposition of some nonutility assets.
Interest expense increased $4.7 million quarter-over-quarter, primarily driven by an increase in debt levels resulting from continued capital investments. 
Turning now to consolidated income taxes. We still expect that our effective income tax rate will be between 37% and 38% this year. Combining all of these items brings us to earnings of $215.4 million or $0.68 per share for the third quarter of 2017 compared to adjusted earnings of $219.1 million or $0.69 per share for the third quarter of 2016.
For the year-to-date, adjusted earnings increased $0.07 to $2.43 per share for the 9 months ended September 30, 2017, compared to an adjusted $2.36 per share for the 9 months ended September 30, 2016. This was largely due to cost control and efficiency gains.
Looking at the cash flow statement at Page 7 of the earnings package, net cash provided by operating activities increased $24.8 million during the 9 months ended September 30, 2017, compared to the same period of 2016. The reduction in working capital and higher operating income for partially offset by $100 million contribution to the pension plan at January 2017.
Our capital expenditures totaled $1.3 billion for the first 9 months of 2017, a $309.1 million increase compared to the same period in 2016, as we continue to invest in our coal infrastructure.
Our debt-to-capital ratio was 51.9% at the end of September, unchanged from the end of 2016. Our calculation continues to treat half of the WEC Energy Group 2007 Series A junior subordinated note as common equity. We're using cash to satisfy any shares required in our 401(k) plan, options and other programs. Going forward, we do not expect to issue any additional shares.
We paid $492.4 million in common stock dividends during the first 9 months of 2017, an increase of $23.8 million over the same period last year.
Moving to sales. We see continued customer growth across our system. At the end of September, our utility were serving approximately 9,000 more electric and 18,000 more natural gas customers than it did the same time a year ago. 
Sales volumes are shown on a comparative basis on Page 13 and 14 of the earnings package. On a year-to-date basis, weather-normalized sales factored out the effects of leap year in 2016.
Overall, normalized sales results for natural gas were slightly above our expectations and retail electric sales were slightly below our expectations.
Turning now to earnings forecasts. We are reaffirming our 2017 earnings guidance of $3.06 a share to $3.12 a share with an expectation of being in the upper end of the range. This projection assumes normal weather for the remainder of the year.
With that, I'll turn things back to Gale.

And a lot of what we're seeing is really enabled by the fact that at the end of June of 2015, we acquired Integra's and we're ahead of plan, clearly, in terms of cost savings resulting from the acquisition. Most all of the cost savings that we've seen so far through the first 9 months of this year, Scott, are already from our Wisconsin operations.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have a question, it's interesting, Wisconsin is has made a lot of progress in terms of the utilities across the state, meaning the renewable portfolio standards. And yet if you do a screen of states that are still very coal heavy, Wisconsin would show u
componenttext: I have a question, it's interesting, Wisconsin is has made a lot of progress in terms of the utilities across the state, meaning the renewable portfolio standards. And yet if you do a screen of states that are still very coal heavy, Wisconsin would show up in the top tier of U.S. states. How do you think this changes for the state as a whole and for your utilities in the state over the next 5 to 7 years? And what do you think the types of resources are that drive that to change? And how does this fit, given the utilities are largely already in compliance with the renewable portfolio standard?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, Michael. Let me try to give you 2 or 3 thoughts on that. First of all, I really can only speak about our utilities, which would be We Energies and Wisconsin Public Service in Green Bay. But when you look at the broader picture, remem
componenttext: It's a good question, Michael. Let me try to give you 2 or 3 thoughts on that. First of all, I really can only speak about our utilities, which would be We Energies and Wisconsin Public Service in Green Bay. But when you look at the broader picture, remember, we have set a goal to reduce carbon emissions by essentially 40% by the year 2030 off 2005 levels. We believe we can do that without significant rate pressure because of what's occurred with the improvement and the efficiency and the costs of some renewables. Believe it or not, I mean, when you look at just what's happened with the efficiency of utility scale solar, I mean, even 3 or 4 years ago for Wisconsin, you might see, oh, gosh, 4,000 megawatts tossed to 4,000 megawatts installed for a large utility scale solar plant in Wisconsin. That's today, down to circa $1,300. So what's going to be driving the restructuring of generation portfolios not just in our state but elsewhere, particularly where they're coal heavy, is really economics. And we're seeing significant economic changes that will allow us to add more renewables to our fleet. In part, we're able to do that and not put pressure on rates because we already have a state-of-the-art backbone, if you will, from the Power the Future units that we already built and are in place. So I think we are very well positioned to continue to take cost out, to continue to reduce carbon emissions. But at the end of the day, I mean, the company's goal is really to maintain a diverse fuel supply, less of coal, clearly less of coal, but at the end of the day, we probably, 10 or 15 years from now, we'll look like a 1/3, 1/3, 1/3. Basically 1/3 coal or 1/3 fossil fuel, 1/3 renewables, 1/3 natural gas. Did that help at all, Michael?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: That helps a lot. I know that's a little bit of a longer-term question so I appreciate answering that as well as you possibly can given what's in the public domain. I have one for Scott, and this is a question of, I mean, I think if I were to take up all
componenttext: That helps a lot. I know that's a little bit of a longer-term question so I appreciate answering that as well as you possibly can given what's in the public domain. I have one for Scott, and this is a question of, I mean, I think if I were to take up all of investors, most people think coming at EEI either this year or next year, some future year, your capital budgets will move higher if there is more renewable investment coming, there's more other investments coming. I guess, the question really I'd ask Scott is how much balance sheet capacity do you think the company has whether it's for incremental rate base growth or shown the ability to successfully integrate another company whether it'd be incremental M&A. How are you thinking about the strength of the balance sheet and how much bloom or excess capacity the current balance sheet has?

componenttext: Yes, that's a good question, Michael. And when we look at it, we're looking at it in a couple of metrics. We're looking at our holding company debt as a percent of total debt, keeping it under 30% but remember that's funding the equity that's making good utility return investments. So we're looking at that and we look at our FFO of the debt, at that 16 to 19 range and looking at our plans and the plan we talked about at EEI, we'll roll it out. We are comfortable with those changes with no additional shares being an issue.

componenttext: Okay. I had a question kind of around the current tax reform proposals and debate in terms of have you thought at all about, I know you have maturities and I think $550 million in June of next year along with $800 million-or-so of short-term debt. Have you thought at all about there's been some proposals to eliminate interest deduction by grandfathering in current debt. So had there been any thought of doing any prefunding, had any of those maturities or short-term debt to try to lock in the deductibility of those interest expenses?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Dan, we thought, first of all, you might buy off all the nondeductible stuff. No, that's not true. That may say this, the whole picture related to interest deductibility, bonus depreciation, the whole picture is pretty murky right now. I mean, we've obvio
componenttext: Dan, we thought, first of all, you might buy off all the nondeductible stuff. No, that's not true. That may say this, the whole picture related to interest deductibility, bonus depreciation, the whole picture is pretty murky right now. I mean, we've obviously had some very good discussions with the tax-writing people in the house, first, Paul Ryan is very involved in the crafting of the legislation. But it is just way too early to think about a prefunding or think about any change in our plan. We're going to have to wait and see, first of all, whether tax reform gets completed and then what the real details are. And there's some thought, there might be an optional election on interest deductibility with a trade-off on another tax deduction item. We'll just have to see. At this point, I think and I think -- I mean, we're obviously looking at the landscape but anything I might tell you is going to be pure speculation until we really understand the details, understand the House passed the budget today which raises the percentage possibility the tax reform will actually take place. But we're just going to have to see the details and then we'll figure out where to go.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the WEC Energy Group's Conference Call for third quarter 2017 results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions]Before the conference call begins, I remind you that all statements in the presenta
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the WEC Energy Group's Conference Call for third quarter 2017 results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions]
Before the conference call begins, I remind you that all statements in the presentation, other than historical facts, are forward-looking statements that involve risk and uncertainties that are subject to change at any time. Such statements are based on management's expectations at the time they are made. In addition to the assumptions and other factors referred to in connection with statements, factors described in WEC Energy Group's latest Form 10-K and subsequent reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated. During the discussion, referenced earnings per share will be based on diluted earnings per share unless otherwise noted.
After the presentation, the conference will be opened to analysts for questions and answers. In conjunction with this call, a package of detailed financial information is posted at wecenergygroup.com. A replay will be available approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of this call.
And now it is my pleasure to introduce Mr. Gale Klappa, Chairman and Interim Chief Executive Officer of WEC Energy Group. Mr. Klappa, the floor is yours.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us as we review our performance for the third quarter of this year. Now before we dive into our update this afternoon, I'd like to take just a moment to thank you for the incredible outpouring
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us as we review our performance for the third quarter of this year. Now before we dive into our update this afternoon, I'd like to take just a moment to thank you for the incredible outpouring of prayers and support and good wishes for Allen Leverett following his stroke earlier this month. I can tell you that Allen has been released from the hospital and is making progress in his recovery. I will continue to serve as Interim Chief Executive for as long as necessary, but the ultimate goal is, obviously, to bring Allen back. But again, your kindness and concern meant a great deal to Allen and his family, and a great deal to all of us as well. My thanks.
Now I'd like to introduce the members of our senior team who are here with me today. We have Scott Lauber, our Chief Financial Officer; Jim Schubilske, Treasurer; Susan Martin, General Counsel; Bill Guc, our Controller; and Beth Straka, Senior Vice President of Corporate Communications and Investor Relations.
We'll begin with our third quarter results. As I'm sure you saw from our news release this morning, we reported third quarter earnings of $0.68 a share. We delivered a solid third quarter, largely driven by effective cost controls.
Our focus on cost management and efficiency gains was a major factor in offsetting the impact of mild summer weather compared to last year's third quarter. Those cool temperatures were particularly noticeable during August, which is normally one of the two warmest months in the Midwest.
Next I'd like to brief you on several developments on the regulatory front and on our capital investments. On August 10, the Wisconsin Public Service Commission unanimously approved our proposed rate settlement. We received our final written order on September 8. Under the approved settlement, base rates for all of our Wisconsin utilities will remain flat for 2018 and for 2019. In total, this will keep base rates flat for 4 years, and essentially gives our customers price certainty through 2019.
The earnings sharing mechanisms that have been in place will be extended through 2019 at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas and a similar mechanism will now be in place for 2018 and 2019 at Wisconsin Public Service. Just a reminder, customers and stockholders share equally in the first 50 basis points of earnings above our allowed rate of return. Anything above the first 50 basis points will flow completely to customers.
Now as part of the agreement, we've also expanded and made permanent certain pricing options for our large electric customers. These options will continue to help many of our customers grow their businesses, create jobs and reduce their energy costs.
Turning to Michigan. I'm pleased to report that we obtained final regulatory approval just yesterday for the construction of new natural gas-fired generation in the Upper Peninsula. We also received all local approvals that are needed to move forward with the project. Our plan is to bring those facilities into commercial service in 2019. And at that time or soon thereafter, we expect to retire our coal-fired power plant at Presque Isle. The approved project calls for a $265 million investment in reciprocating internal combustion engines. It will be capable of generating up to 180 megawatts of electricity. These units, which will be owned by our utility subsidiary in Michigan, Upper Michigan Energy Resources, provide a long-term generation solution for customers in the Upper Peninsula, and that includes the iron ore mine owned by Cleveland-Cliffs.
And now for an update on Illinois. We continue to make progress on the Peoples Gas system modernization program. Since we've acquired Peoples Gas, we've made significant improvements in a number of important metrics. We've lowered contractor construction costs by 15%. We've achieved a 70% decline in customer complaints. Construction time lines have been reduced by more than 25%, and I'm pleased to say that our working relationship with City of Chicago is greatly improved.
Our system modernization program, as you've heard, is designed to make the gas distribution network in Chicago safer, more reliable, less expensive to maintain. You may recall, we still have an open docket on the preferred approach to this long-term project. We expect a decision by the Illinois Commerce Commission by year-end. And consistent with our 2017 plan, we're on track to invest approximately $300 million on the effort in Chicago this year.
Turning now to our operations in Minnesota. On October 13, Minnesota Energy Resources filed a rate case with the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission. We're seeking to increase natural gas base rates by $12.6 million or approximately 5%. We have also requested, under the procedures available in Minnesota, to self-implement an increase of $9.5 million or 3.8% effective January 1 of 2018.
A final decision on new permanent rates is not expected until the first quarter of 2019. I'd also like to update you on our recent FERC decision related to system support resource payments for the Presque Isle Power Plant in Michigan. In its decision, FERC ordered a refund of $22.6 million associated with the payments that we received for the period February of 2014 through January of 2015.
As you may recall, this is very close to the amount that the administrative law judge recommended last year. So consistent with our previous statements, the amount of the refund will not result in a dollar-for dollar reduction in net income, and we have taken the FERC decision into account for our year-end guidance.
Next, I'd like to remind everyone that we will be rolling out our new 5-year capital forecast at the EEI Finance Conference in early November. Over the past few months, Allen shared the developing plan with me and my role as Chairman of the Board. In the past few weeks, I have, of course, reviewed the capital plan in great detail, and I share Allen's optimism about the direction of the plan. Now one piece of that new 5-year plan has just been put in place.
Our Wisconsin Public Service utility in Green Bay, along with Wisconsin Power and Light and Madison Gas and Electric, have purchased the Forward Wind Energy Center from Invenergy. The total purchase price is approximately $174 million. We will own 44.6% of the facility with an investment of approximately $78 million. Forward consists of 86 GE wind turbines with a capacity of about 130 megawatts. The wind farm is located 10 miles south of Fond du Lac County in the eastern part of the state. If approved, Wisconsin Public Service customers will see real savings because we will be able to eliminate the existing power purchase agreement.
Pending regulatory approvals closing on the Forward Wind Center could take place next spring. Again, we look forward to sharing more about our new 5-year capital plan at EEI, and we really look forward to the opportunities that lie ahead.
And speaking of opportunity, you may have heard about the blockbuster announcement this summer. The announcement that Foxconn has chosen Wisconsin for one of the largest economic development projects in American history. Based on revenue, Foxconn is the fourth largest tech company in the world. And Foxconn has decided to bring a brand-new technology called 8K to the United States. The company plans to invest $10 billion to build a massive production plant that could employ as many as 13,000 people in Racine County, just south of Milwaukee. We expect the electric demand from this Foxconn campus to be more than 200 megawatts. That's approximately 3x the size of our current largest Wisconsin customer. And that does not include the demand that will develop from the suppliers that will also need to locate near the Foxconn facility. Foxconn has chosen a site in Southeastern Wisconsin that is perfectly situated on our transmission network. We will not need to build any new generation. Our state-of-the-art network is well equipped today to provide reliable, low-cost energy to Foxconn.
And on top of that, folks, if you like gummy bears, and you know who doesn't, I have more news for you. The German candymaker HARIBO has also selected Wisconsin for its first-ever manufacturing facility in North America. So as you can see, the manufacturing economy in Wisconsin is alive and well.
And now with details on our third quarter results and our outlook for the remainder of 2017, here's our esteemed Chief Financial Officer, Scott Lauber. Scott?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gale. Our GAAP earnings were unchanged from the third quarter of 2016 at $0.68 per share. You may recall that our 2016 third quarter earnings included $0.01 of acquisition costs. Excluding these costs, our adjusted earnings were $0.69 in the th
componenttext:
Thank you, Gale. Our GAAP earnings were unchanged from the third quarter of 2016 at $0.68 per share. You may recall that our 2016 third quarter earnings included $0.01 of acquisition costs. Excluding these costs, our adjusted earnings were $0.69 in the third quarter of 2016. Our results were primarily driven by a return to normal weather conditions, offset by positive impact of cost control. Weather in 2016 was 43% warmer than normal in Southeastern Wisconsin. The earnings packet placed on our website this morning includes a comparison of third quarter and year-to-date 2017 and 2016 results for GAAP and adjusted. There were no adjustments made to GAAP earnings in 2017.
My focus will be on the quarter, beginning with operating income by segment and then other income, interest expense and income taxes. Referring to Page 9 of the earning packet, our consolidated operating income in the third quarter of 2017 was $393.6 million compared to an adjusted $402.5 million in the third quarter of 2016, a decrease of $8.9 million.
Starting with the Wisconsin segment, operating income decreased $19.4 million quarter-over-quarter. Lower margin was driven by a return to normal weather and a normal fuel recovery pattern. This was offset by operations and maintenance expense that was $39.9 million lower compared to the third quarter of 2016. Last year, we recorded $18.6 million in operations and maintenance expense related to the earnings sharing mechanism in place at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas.
In the third quarter of 2017, our Illinois segment recognized an operating income increase of $800,000 compared to the third quarter of 2016. The increase was primarily driven by continued investment in the gas system modernization program.
As expected, operating loss in our Other States segment increased $2.1 million, driven by higher depreciation and amortization expense resulting from an increase in capital investments in our gas distribution utilities.
Turning now to our non-utility energy infrastructure segment. As a reminder, this segment contains the operations of Bluewater Natural Gas Holding, which was acquired on June 30 of this year as well as a result of the Power the Future plants. For the third quarter, operating income in this segment was up $9.7 million. Bluewater Natural Gas Holding contributed $5.9 million to operating income in 2017. Operating income from our Power the Future plants increased $3.8 million, reflecting the additional investment at these plants since the third quarter of 2016.
Operating income at our corporate and other segment was $1.1 million for the third quarter of 2017, an increase of $2.1 million from the adjusted operating loss in the third quarter of 2016. Taking the changes for these segments together, we arrived at $8.9 million decrease in adjusted operating income.
During the third quarter of 2017, earnings from our equity investment in American Transmission Company totaled $39.2 million, an increase of $900,000 compared to the same quarter of 2016.
Other income net increased by $8.9 million quarter-over-quarter. This was largely due to 2 items, higher investment gains related to our deferred compensation plan and we incurred losses in our third quarter of 2016 related to the disposition of some nonutility assets.
Interest expense increased $4.7 million quarter-over-quarter, primarily driven by an increase in debt levels resulting from continued capital investments.
Turning now to consolidated income taxes. We still expect that our effective income tax rate will be between 37% and 38% this year. Combining all of these items brings us to earnings of $215.4 million or $0.68 per share for the third quarter of 2017, compared to adjusted earnings of $219.1 million or $0.69 per share for the third quarter of 2016.
For the year-to-date, adjusted earnings increased $0.07 to $2.43 per share for the 9 months ended September 30, 2017, compared to an adjusted $2.36 per share for the 9 months ended September 30, 2016. This was largely due to cost control and efficiency gains.
Looking at the cash flow statement on Page 7 of the earnings package, net cash provided by operating activities increased $24.8 million during the 9 months ended September 30, 2017, compared to the same period in 2016. The reduction in working capital and higher operating income were partially offset by a $100 million contribution to the pension plan in January 2017.
Our capital expenditures totaled $1.3 billion for the first 9 months of 2017, a $309.1 million increase compared to the same period in 2016, as we continue to invest in our core infrastructure.
Our debt-to-capital ratio was 51.9% at the end of September, unchanged from the end of 2016. Our calculation continues to treat half of the WEC Energy Group 2007 Series A Junior Subordinated Notes as common equity. We're using cash to satisfy any shares required in our 401(k) plan, options and other programs. Going forward, we do not expect to issue any additional shares.
We paid $492.4 million in common stock dividends during the first 9 months of 2017, an increase of $23.8 million over the same period last year.
Moving to sales. We see continued customer growth across our system. At the end of September, our utilities were serving approximately 9,000 more electric and 18,000 more natural gas customers than it did the same time a year ago.
Sales volumes are shown on a comparative basis on Page 13 and 14 of the earnings package. On a year-to-date basis, weather-normalized sales factor out the effects of leap year in 2016. Overall normalized sales results for natural gas were slightly above our expectations and retail electric sales were slightly below our expectations.
Turning now to our earnings forecasts. We are reaffirming our 2017 earnings guidance of $3.06 a share to $3.12 a share with an expectation of being in the upper end of the range. This projection assumes normal weather for the remainder of the year.
With that, I'll turn things back to Gale.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have a question, it's interesting, Wisconsin is -- has made a lot of progress in terms of the utilities across the state, meeting the renewable portfolio standards. And yet if you do a screen of states that are still very coal heavy, Wisconsin would sho
componenttext: I have a question, it's interesting, Wisconsin is -- has made a lot of progress in terms of the utilities across the state, meeting the renewable portfolio standards. And yet if you do a screen of states that are still very coal heavy, Wisconsin would show up in the top tier of U.S. states. How do you think this changes for the state as a whole and for your utilities in the state over the next 5 to 7 years? And what do you think the types of resources are that drive that to change? And how does this fit, given what -- given the utilities are largely already in compliance with the renewable portfolio standard?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, Michael. Let me try to give you 2 or 3 thoughts on that. I mean, first of all, I really can only speak about our utilities, which would be We Energies and Wisconsin Public Service in Green Bay. But when you look at the broader pictur
componenttext: It's a good question, Michael. Let me try to give you 2 or 3 thoughts on that. I mean, first of all, I really can only speak about our utilities, which would be We Energies and Wisconsin Public Service in Green Bay. But when you look at the broader picture, remember, we have set a goal to reduce carbon emissions by essentially 40% by the year 2030 off 2005 levels. We believe we can do that without significant rate pressure because of what's occurred with the improvement and the efficiency and the cost of some renewables. Believe it or not, I mean, when you look at just what's happened with the efficiency of utility-scale solar, I mean, even 3 or 4 years ago for Wisconsin, you might see, oh, gosh, 4,000 megawatts installed -- cost of 4,000 megawatts installed for a large utility-scale solar plant in Wisconsin. That's today down to circa $1,300. So what's going to be driving the restructuring of generation portfolios, not just in our state but elsewhere, particularly, where they're coal heavy, is really economics. And we're seeing significant economic changes that will allow us to add more renewables to our fleet. In part, we're able to do that and not put pressure on rates because we already have a state-of-the-art backbone, if you will, from the Power the Future units that we've already built and are in place. So I think we are very well positioned to continue to take costs out, to continue to reduce carbon emissions. But at the end of the day, I mean, the company's goal is really to maintain a diverse fuel supply, less of coal, clearly less of coal. But at the end of the day, we probably, 10 or 15 years from now, will look like a 1/3, 1/3, 1/3. Basically 1/3 coal, 1/3 fossil fuel, 1/3 renewables, 1/3 natural gas. Did that help at all, Michael?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: That helps a lot. I know that's a little bit of a longer-term question, so I appreciate you answering that as well as you possibly can given what's in the public domain. I have one for Scott, and this is a question of, I mean, I think if I were to take a
componenttext: That helps a lot. I know that's a little bit of a longer-term question, so I appreciate you answering that as well as you possibly can given what's in the public domain. I have one for Scott, and this is a question of, I mean, I think if I were to take a poll of investors, most people think coming at EEI either this year or next year or some future year, your capital budgets will move higher if there is more renewable investment coming, there's more other investment coming. I guess, the question really I'd ask you, Scott, is how much balance sheet capacity do you think the company has whether it's for incremental rate base growth or you've shown the ability to successfully integrate another company whether it'd be incremental M&A. How are you thinking about the strength of the balance sheet and how much bloom or excess capacity the current balance sheet has?

componenttext: Yes, that's a good question, Michael. And when we look at it, we're looking at it in a couple of metrics. We look at our holding company debt as a percent of total debt, keeping it under 30%, but remember that's funding the equity that's making good utility return investments. So we're looking at debt, and we look at our FFO to debt at 16% to 19% range and looking at our plans and the plan we talked about at EEI, we'll roll it out. We are going to be comfortable in those changes with no additional shares being issued.

componenttext: Okay. I had a question kind of around the current tax reform proposals and debate in terms of have you thought at all about, I note you have amount of maturities, and I think $550 million in June in next year along with $800 million-or-so of short-term debt. Have you thought at all about, there's been some proposals to eliminate interest deduction by grandfathering in current debt. So any thought of doing any prefunding of any of those maturities or short-term debt to try to lock in the deductibility of those interest expenses?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Dan, we thought, first of all, you might buy up all the nondeductible stuff. No, that's not true. Let me say this, the whole picture related to interest deductibility, bonus depreciation -- the whole picture is pretty murky right now. I mean, we've, obvio
componenttext: Dan, we thought, first of all, you might buy up all the nondeductible stuff. No, that's not true. Let me say this, the whole picture related to interest deductibility, bonus depreciation -- the whole picture is pretty murky right now. I mean, we've, obviously, had some very good discussions with the tax-writing people in the House. First of all, Ryan is very involved in the crafting of the legislation. But it is just way too early to think about a prefunding or think about any change in our plan. We're going to have to see, first of all, whether tax reform actually gets completed and then what the real details are. And there's some thought that there might be an optional election on interest deductibility with a trade-off on another tax deduction item. We'll just have to see. At this point, I think anything that -- I mean, we're, obviously, looking at the landscape, but anything that I might tell you would be pure speculation until we really understand the details. I understand the House passed a budget today, which raises the percentage possibility the tax reform will actually take place. But we're just going to have to see the detail and then we'll figure out where to go.

componenttext: Yes, we'll be happy to do that. And I'll ask Scott to chime in as well. Let me just say this. I'm -- you've heard me say this before. So I wouldn't be overly concerned one way or another about 1 quarter's results, but we are seeing some, what Scott calls, green shoots in 3 or 4 specific industry sectors. And we'll let Scott tell you about those.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the WEC Energy Group's Conference Call for third quarter 2017 results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions]Before the conference call begins, I remind you that all statements in the presenta
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the WEC Energy Group's Conference Call for third quarter 2017 results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions]
Before the conference call begins, I remind you that all statements in the presentation, other than historical facts, are forward-looking statements that involve risk and uncertainties that are subject to change at any time. Such statements are based on management's expectations at the time that they are made. In addition to the assumptions and other factors referred to in connection with statements, factors described in WEC Energy Group's latest Form 10-K and subsequent reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated. During the discussion, referenced earnings per share will be based on diluted earnings per share unless otherwise noted.
After the presentation, the conference will be opened to analysts for questions and answers. In conjunction with this call, a package of detailed financial information is posted at wecenergygroup.com. A replay will be available approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of this call.
And now it is my pleasure to introduce Mr. Gale Klappa, Chairman and Interim Chief Executive Officer of WEC Energy Group. Mr. Klappa, the floor is yours.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us as we review our performance for the third quarter of this year. Now before we dive into our update this afternoon, I'd like to take just a moment to thank you for the incredible outpouring
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us as we review our performance for the third quarter of this year. Now before we dive into our update this afternoon, I'd like to take just a moment to thank you for the incredible outpouring of prayers and support and good wishes for Allen Leverett following his stroke earlier this month. I can tell you that Allen has been released from the hospital and is making progress in his recovery. I will continue to serve as Interim Chief Executive for as long as necessary, but the ultimate goal is, obviously, to bring Allen back. But again, your kindness and concern have meant a great deal to Allen and his family, and a great deal to all of us as well. My thanks.
Now I'd like to introduce the members of our senior team who are here with me today. We have Scott Lauber, our Chief Financial Officer; Jim Schubilske, Treasurer; Susan Martin, General Counsel; Bill Guc, our Controller; and Beth Straka, Senior Vice President of Corporate Communications and Investor Relations.
We'll begin with our third quarter results. As I'm sure you saw from our news release this morning, we reported third quarter earnings of $0.68 a share. We delivered a solid third quarter, largely driven by effective cost controls.
Our focus on cost management and efficiency gains was a major factor in offsetting the impact of mild summer weather compared to last year's third quarter. Those cool temperatures were particularly noticeable during August, which is normally one of the two warmest months in the Midwest.
Next I'd like to brief you on several developments on the regulatory front and on our capital investments. On August 10, the Wisconsin Public Service Commission unanimously approved our proposed rate settlement. We received our final written order on September 8. Under the approved settlement, base rates for all of our Wisconsin utilities will remain flat for 2018 and for 2019. In total, this will keep base rates flat for 4 years, and essentially gives our customers price certainty through 2019.
The earnings sharing mechanisms that have been in place will be extended through 2019 at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas and a similar mechanism will now be in place for 2018 and 2019 at Wisconsin Public Service. Just a reminder, customers and stockholders share equally in the first 50 basis points of earnings above our allowed rate of return. Anything above the first 50 basis points will flow completely to customers.
Now as part of the agreement, we've also expanded and made permanent certain pricing options for our large electric customers. These options will continue to help many of our customers grow their businesses, create jobs and reduce their energy costs.
Turning to Michigan. I'm pleased to report that we obtained final regulatory approval just yesterday for the construction of new natural gas-fired generation in the Upper Peninsula. We also received all local approvals that are needed to move forward with the project. Our plan is to bring those facilities into commercial service in 2019. And at that time or soon thereafter, we expect to retire our coal-fired power plant at Presque Isle. The approved project calls for a $265 million investment in reciprocating internal combustion engines. It will be capable of generating up to 180 megawatts of electricity. These units, which will be owned by our utility subsidiary in Michigan, Upper Michigan Energy Resources, provide a long-term generation solution for customers in the Upper Peninsula, and that includes the iron ore mine owned by Cleveland-Cliffs.
And now for an update on Illinois. We continue to make progress on the Peoples Gas system modernization program. Since we've acquired Peoples Gas, we've made significant improvements in a number of important metrics. We've lowered contractor construction costs by 15%. We've achieved a 70% decline in customer complaints. Construction time lines have been reduced by more than 25%, and I'm pleased to say that our working relationship with the City of Chicago is greatly improved.
Our system modernization program, as you've heard, is designed to make the gas distribution network in Chicago safer, more reliable, less expensive to maintain. You may recall, we still have an open docket on the preferred approach to this long-term project. We expect a decision by the Illinois Commerce Commission by year end. And consistent with our 2017 plan, we're on track to invest approximately $300 million on the effort in Chicago this year.
Turning now to our operations in Minnesota. On October 13, Minnesota Energy Resources filed a rate case with the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission. We're seeking to increase natural gas base rates by $12.6 million or approximately 5%. We have also requested, under the procedures available in Minnesota, to self-implement an increase of $9.5 million or 3.8% effective January 1 of 2018.
A final decision on new permanent rates is not expected until the first quarter of 2019. I'd also like to update you on our recent FERC decision related to system support resource payments for the Presque Isle Power Plant in Michigan. In its decision, FERC ordered a refund of $22.6 million associated with the payments that we received for the period February of 2014 through January of 2015.
As you may recall, this is very close to the amount that the administrative law judge recommended last year. So consistent with our previous statements, the amount of the refund will not result in a dollar-for-dollar reduction in net income, and we have taken the FERC decision into account for our year end guidance.
Next, I'd like to remind everyone that we will be rolling out our new 5-year capital forecast at the EEI Finance Conference in early November. Over the past few months, Allen shared the developing plan with me in my role as Chairman of the Board. In the past few weeks, I have, of course, reviewed the capital plan in great detail, and I share Allen's optimism about the direction of the plan. Now one piece of that new 5-year plan has just been put in place.
Our Wisconsin Public Service utility in Green Bay, along with Wisconsin Power and Light and Madison Gas and Electric, have purchased the Forward Wind Energy Center from Invenergy. The total purchase price is approximately $174 million. We will own 44.6% of the facility with an investment of approximately $78 million. Forward consists of 86 GE wind turbines with a capacity of about 130 megawatts. The wind farm is located 10 miles south of Fond du Lac in the eastern part of the state. If approved, Wisconsin Public Service customers will see real savings because we will be able to eliminate the existing power purchase agreement.
Pending regulatory approvals closing on the Forward Wind Center could take place next spring. Again, we look forward to sharing more about our new 5-year capital plan at EEI, and we really look forward to the opportunities that lie ahead.
And speaking of opportunity, you may have heard about the blockbuster announcement this summer. The announcement that Foxconn has chosen Wisconsin for one of the largest economic development projects in American history. Based on revenue, Foxconn is the fourth largest tech company in the world. And Foxconn has decided to bring a brand-new technology called 8K to the United States. The company plans to invest $10 billion to build a massive production plant that could employ as many as 13,000 people in Racine County, just south of Milwaukee. We expect the electric demand from this Foxconn campus to be more than 200 megawatts. That's approximately 3x the size of our current largest Wisconsin customer. And that does not include the demand that will develop from the suppliers that will also need to locate near the Foxconn facility. Foxconn has chosen a site in southeastern Wisconsin that is perfectly situated on our transmission network. We will not need to build any new generation. Our state-of-the-art network is well equipped today to provide reliable, low-cost energy to Foxconn.
And on top of that, folks, if you like gummy bears, and you know who doesn't, I have more news for you. The German candymaker HARIBO has also selected Wisconsin for its first-ever manufacturing facility in North America. So as you can see, the manufacturing economy in Wisconsin is alive and well.
And now with details on our third quarter results and our outlook for the remainder of 2017, here's our esteemed Chief Financial Officer, Scott Lauber. Scott?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gale. Our GAAP earnings were unchanged from the third quarter of 2016 at $0.68 per share. You may recall that our 2016 third quarter earnings included $0.01 of acquisition costs. Excluding these costs, our adjusted earnings were $0.69 in the th
componenttext:
Thank you, Gale. Our GAAP earnings were unchanged from the third quarter of 2016 at $0.68 per share. You may recall that our 2016 third quarter earnings included $0.01 of acquisition costs. Excluding these costs, our adjusted earnings were $0.69 in the third quarter of 2016. Our results were primarily driven by a return to normal weather conditions, offset by positive impact of cost control. Weather in 2016 was 43% warmer than normal in southeastern Wisconsin. The earnings packet placed on our website this morning includes a comparison of third quarter and year-to-date 2017 and 2016 results, both GAAP and adjusted. There were no adjustments made to GAAP earnings in 2017.
My focus will be on the quarter, beginning with operating income by segment and then other income, interest expense and income taxes. Referring to Page 9 of the earning packet, our consolidated operating income in the third quarter of 2017 was $393.6 million compared to the adjusted $402.5 million in the third quarter of 2016, a decrease of $8.9 million.
Starting with the Wisconsin segment, operating income decreased $19.4 million quarter-over-quarter. Lower margin was driven by a return to normal weather and a normal fuel recovery pattern. This was offset by operations and maintenance expense that was $39.9 million lower compared to the third quarter of 2016. Last year, we recorded $18.6 million in operations and maintenance expense related to the earnings sharing mechanism in place at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas.
In the third quarter of 2017, our Illinois segment recognized an operating income increase of $800,000 compared to the third quarter of 2016. The increase was primarily driven by continued investment in the gas system modernization program.
As expected, operating loss in our Other States segment increased $2.1 million, driven by higher depreciation and amortization expense resulting from an increase in capital investments in our gas distribution utilities.
Turning now to our non-utility energy infrastructure segment. As a reminder, this segment contains the operations of Bluewater Natural Gas Holding, which was acquired on June 30 of this year as well as a result of the Power the Future plants. For the third quarter, operating income in this segment was up $9.7 million. Bluewater Natural Gas Holding contributed $5.9 million to operating income in 2017. Operating income from our Power the Future plants increased $3.8 million, reflecting the additional investment at these plants since the third quarter of 2016.
Operating income at our Corporate and Other segment was $1.1 million for the third quarter of 2017, an increase of $2.1 million from the adjusted operating loss in the third quarter of 2016. Taking the changes for these segments together, we arrived at $8.9 million decrease in adjusted operating income.
During the third quarter of 2017, earnings from our equity investment in American Transmission Company totaled $39.2 million, an increase of $900,000 compared to the same quarter of 2016.
Other income net increased by $8.9 million quarter-over-quarter. This was largely due to 2 items, higher investment gains related to our deferred compensation plan and we incurred losses in our third quarter of 2016 related to the disposition of some nonutility assets.
Interest expense increased $4.7 million quarter-over-quarter, primarily driven by an increase in debt levels resulting from continued capital investments.
Turning now to consolidated income taxes. We still expect that our effective income tax rate will be between 37% and 38% this year. Combining all of these items brings us to earnings of $215.4 million or $0.68 per share for the third quarter of 2017, compared to adjusted earnings of $219.1 million or $0.69 per share for the third quarter of 2016.
For the year-to-date, adjusted earnings increased $0.07 to $2.43 per share for the 9 months ended September 30, 2017, compared to an adjusted $2.36 per share for the 9 months ended September 30, 2016. This was largely due to cost control and efficiency gains.
Looking at the cash flow statement on Page 7 of the earnings package, net cash provided by operating activities increased $24.8 million during the 9 months ended September 30, 2017, compared to the same period in 2016. The reduction in working capital and higher operating income were partially offset by a $100 million contribution to the pension plan in January 2017.
Our capital expenditures totaled $1.3 billion for the first 9 months of 2017, a $309.1 million increase compared to the same period in 2016, as we continue to invest in our core infrastructure.
Our debt-to-capital ratio was 51.9% at the end of September, unchanged from the end of 2016. Our calculation continues to treat half of the WEC Energy Group 2007 Series A Junior Subordinated Notes as common equity. We're using cash to satisfy any shares required in our 401(k) plan, options and other programs. Going forward, we do not expect to issue any additional shares.
We paid $492.4 million in common stock dividends during the first 9 months of 2017, an increase of $23.8 million over the same period last year.
Moving to sales. We see continued customer growth across our system. At the end of September, our utilities were serving approximately 9,000 more electric and 18,000 more natural gas customers than it did the same time a year ago.
Sales volumes are shown on a comparative basis on Page 13 and 14 of the earnings package. On a year-to-date basis, weather-normalized sales factor out the effects of leap year in 2016. Overall normalized sales results for natural gas were slightly above our expectations and retail electric sales were slightly below our expectations.
Turning now to our earnings forecasts. We are reaffirming our 2017 earnings guidance of $3.06 a share to $3.12 a share with an expectation of being in the upper end of the range. This projection assumes normal weather for the remainder of the year.
With that, I'll turn things back to Gale.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have a question, it's interesting, Wisconsin is -- has made a lot of progress in terms of the utilities across the state, meeting the renewable portfolio standards. And yet if you did a screen of states that are still very coal heavy, Wisconsin would sh
componenttext: I have a question, it's interesting, Wisconsin is -- has made a lot of progress in terms of the utilities across the state, meeting the renewable portfolio standards. And yet if you did a screen of states that are still very coal heavy, Wisconsin would show up in the top tier of U.S. states. How do you think this changes for the state as a whole and for your utilities in the state over the next 5 to 7 years? And what do you think the types of resources are that drive that to change? And how does this fit, given what -- given the utilities are largely already in compliance with the renewable portfolio standard?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a good question, Michael. Let me try to give you 2 or 3 thoughts on that. I mean, first of all, I really can only speak about our utilities, which would be We Energies and Wisconsin Public Service in Green Bay. But when you look at the broader
componenttext: Well, it's a good question, Michael. Let me try to give you 2 or 3 thoughts on that. I mean, first of all, I really can only speak about our utilities, which would be We Energies and Wisconsin Public Service in Green Bay. But when you look at the broader picture, remember, we have set a goal to reduce carbon emissions by essentially 40% by the year 2030 off 2005 levels. We believe we can do that without significant rate pressure because of what's occurred with the improvement and the efficiency and the cost of some renewables. Believe it or not, I mean, when you look at just what's happened with the efficiency of utility-scale solar, I mean, even 3 or 4 years ago for Wisconsin, you might see, oh, gosh, $4,000 a megawatt installed -- cost of $4,000 a megawatt installed for a large utility-scale solar plant in Wisconsin. That's today down to circa $1,300. So what's going to be driving the restructuring of generation portfolios, not just in our state but elsewhere, particularly, where they're coal heavy, is really economics. And we're seeing significant economic changes that will allow us to add more renewables to our fleet. In part, we're able to do that and not put pressure on rates because we already have a state-of-the-art backbone, if you will, from the Power the Future units that we've already built and are in place. So I think we are very well positioned to continue to take costs out, to continue to reduce carbon emissions. But at the end of the day, I mean, the company's goal is really to maintain a diverse fuel supply, less of coal, clearly less of coal. But at the end of the day, we probably, 10 or 15 years from now, will look like a 1/3, 1/3, 1/3. Basically 1/3 coal, or 1/3 fossil fuel, 1/3 renewables, 1/3 natural gas. Did that help at all, Michael?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: That helps a lot. I know that's a little bit of a longer-term question, so I appreciate answering that as well as you possibly can given what's in the public domain. I have 1 for Scott, and this is a question of, I mean, I think if I were to take a poll o
componenttext: That helps a lot. I know that's a little bit of a longer-term question, so I appreciate answering that as well as you possibly can given what's in the public domain. I have 1 for Scott, and this is a question of, I mean, I think if I were to take a poll of investors, most people think coming at EEI either this year or next year or some future year, your capital budgets will move higher if there is more renewable investment coming, there's more other investment coming. I guess, the question really I'd ask you, Scott, is how much balance sheet capacity do you think the company has whether it's for incremental rate base growth or you've shown the ability to successfully integrate another company whether it'd be incremental M&A. How are you thinking about the strength of the balance sheet and how much room or excess capacity the current balance sheet has?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question, Michael. And when we look at it, we're looking at it in a couple of metrics. We look at our holding company debt as a percent of total debt, keeping it under 30%, but remember that's funding the equity that's making good utili
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question, Michael. And when we look at it, we're looking at it in a couple of metrics. We look at our holding company debt as a percent of total debt, keeping it under 30%, but remember that's funding the equity that's making good utility return investments. So we're looking at that, and we look at our FFO to debt at 16% to 19% range and looking at our plans and the plan we talked about at EEI, we'll roll it out. We are going to be comfortable in those changes with no additional shares being issued.

componenttextpreview: Okay. I had a question kind of around the current tax reform proposals and debate in terms of have you thought at all about, I note you have amount of maturities, and I think $550 million in June in next year along with $800 million-or-so of short-term de
componenttext: Okay. I had a question kind of around the current tax reform proposals and debate in terms of have you thought at all about, I note you have amount of maturities, and I think $550 million in June in next year along with $800 million-or-so of short-term debt. Have you thought at all about, there's been some proposals to eliminate interest deduction by grandfathering in current debt. So been any thought of doing any prefunding of any of those maturities or short-term debt to try to lock in the deductibility of those interest expenses?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, Dan, we thought, first of all, you might buy up all the nondeductible stuff. No, that's not true. Let me say this, the whole picture related to interest deductibility, bonus depreciation -- the whole picture is pretty murky right now. I mean, we've,
componenttext: Well, Dan, we thought, first of all, you might buy up all the nondeductible stuff. No, that's not true. Let me say this, the whole picture related to interest deductibility, bonus depreciation -- the whole picture is pretty murky right now. I mean, we've, obviously, had some very good discussions with the tax-writing people in the House. Of course Paul Ryan is very involved in the crafting of the legislation. But it is just way too early to think about a prefunding or think about any change in our plan. We're going to have to see, first of all, whether tax reform actually gets completed and then what the real details are. And there's some thought that there might be an optional election on interest deductibility with a trade-off on another tax deduction item. We'll just have to see. At this point, I think anything that -- I mean, we're, obviously, looking at the landscape, but anything that I might tell you would be pure speculation until we really understand the details. I understand the House passed a budget today, which raises the percentage possibility the tax reform will actually take place. But we're just going to have to see the details and then we'll figure out where to go.

componenttext: Yes, we'll be happy to do that. And I'll ask Scott to chime in as well. Let me just say this. I'm -- and you've heard me say this before. On a very short-term basis, I'm quite skeptical of our ability to weather normalize accurately. When you have -- and you're correct, industrial demand should be less weather sensitive than any other group of customers, but there's still some weather sensitivity. So I think we need to look over a much longer period of time than just 1 quarter versus a comparison to another quarter where it was 43% warmer than normal. So I wouldn't be overly concerned one way or another about 1 quarter's results, but we are seeing some, what Scott calls, green shoots in 3 or 4 specific industry sectors. And we'll let Scott tell you about those.

componenttext: Yes, so, exactly, Gale. We have basically 4 sectors: the food and food product sector, the paper products area actually rubber and plastics and another sector that just kind of showed up this quarter is fabricating metal. So encouraged by what we are starting to see in these individual sectors and hopefully that growth continues as we move forward here.

componenttext: And for what it's worth, Scott and I have talked about this, the Foxconn demand growth that -- the demand growth we'll see from Foxconn and the demand growth we'll see from HARIBO and several of the other really good economic development projects that have come to fruition, we haven't yet put those in our numbers. So, for example, Foxconn, I wouldn't think would affect our industrial sales until probably 2020, and then they'll ramp-up, obviously, from the start. But our projections today really do not include any of those recent developments. Correct, Scott?
